Shooting any gun from a solidified position, such as vicing the gun to the ground so that it won't move when shot, will destroy the gun.  For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction, so when the cartridge is struck and the slug is shot from the barrel of the weapon, recoil is produced as the opposite reaction.  Vicing a gun to the ground prevents recoil, and this energy will instead destroy the action of the weapon.  This is what our physics teacher taught us!

Dimensional differences due to the different chambering and other slight dimensional differences, but nothing that would constitute being "completely different".

If you are implying they are fundamentally different rifles that would be far from the truth, they both have exactly the same design approach and manufacture, they however have many incompatible parts as not only is the 74 chambered for a different cartridge, but the design of the bolt, muzzle break etc. have been improved. If this was an AKM the very tip of the barrel would be sloped. While what you say is correct about the AKM, it's not the rifle being used in this video.

It's an ak-74 because of a couple of reasons.
1) there's no wood on this rifle, all original ak-47 designs used wood for the handle, stock etc. on the gun featured in this video, it is obviously plastic on the handle and under the barrel.
2) the tip of the barrel on this rifle is that of an ak-74, or an ak-101 both of which are very similar.
3) the tube that carries the gas to push the bolt back attaches to the barrel at a .90 degree angle on this rifle. But on an ak-47 it would be on a slope.

Oblong depression on the receiver just above the magazine well & the perpendicular style gas block. Indicative of an AKM style post 1960s stamped receiver (AK-47 has machined receiver with a larger, rectangular depression), and of an AK-74 style gas block in use from 1974 onward. That isn't a true AK-47, nor is it a pure AKM; but that curved magazine is indicative of the 7.62x39mm chambering of the rifle. So I think that is a civilian variant of the AK-103, available from a few firms in the U.S.

Water is faster because the initial acceleration is hampered in the air case by leakage in the front of the piston there.  Get rid of that leak and the air will still probably not keep up at first because of the compressibility of air vs. water.  ie. there is a propagation of the energy that happens in air that is much much slower. 330- 343m/sec.  Where in water 4.3X faster.  On the other side of the piston is a fluid dynamic problem but there's a big opening so it's just accelerating H2Omass

Also, if the fluid pressure are the same around the rifle. The muzzle has larger opening. So, water/air will flow out of muzzle but not gas port. Only when bullet is between gas port and muzzle, the fluid which is the gas would go into the gas port. The water doesn't transfer "faster" information for this part.
Compression is a hell of a drug.

And it doesn't mean it works better. The gas operated auto rifle has the venting for reasons. They don't need the extra energy after venting. The extra energy would cause higher bolt recoil speed, larger impact on the bottom of receiver, of course, short life.

I don't think it is related to fluid compressibility. Probably, it is related to venting environment confined or not. In the water, the venting holes on the cylinder are surrounding by water, which means the space is more confined than in the air. So, the gas pressure inside cylinder drops slower in the water and then the gas pushes the bolt longer. You can observe that the bolt would recoil faster if no venting too.

A bullet provides the required mass to push/compress the water out of the barrel, and also serves to "seal" the combustion between the bullet and the fired round case. A blank would be simply burning powder against a wall of water - probably would not work as well. Blanks are very sensitive in semi-auto firearms, and normally require a blank fire adapter to operate correctly at all - the blank firing adapter is a sort of choke device that raises the gas pressure within the barrel.

The bolt most likely moved "faster" under water because the operating pulse acting upon the piston started sooner. When the bullet left the chamber, it likely compressed some of the water into the gas port. I'm going to go with the incompressibility of water. The air in front of the piston acted as a shock absorber, sucking away some of the energy of the gasses and converting it to more heat and reducing the force applied to the bolt.

Water is incompressible and will transmit all* the force applied to the bolt, causing greater acceleration and faster bolt action.

*Water almost certainly has some compressibility, but it's miniscule compared to air.
